body_html:
@ebrevdo: For me pip finds and installs backports.weakref (version 1.0rc1) just fine without giving any version number:

$ pip --version
pip 9.0.1 from /usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages (python 3.6)

$ pip install --user backports.weakref
Collecting backports.weakref
  Using cached backports.weakref-1.0rc1-py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: backports.weakref
Successfully installed backports.weakref-1.0rc1

The >=1.0rc version check from the setup.py creates the entry Requires-Dist: backports.weakref (>=1.0rc1) inside the wheels METADATA file. Installing the package and pulling the dependency also works fine for me with this using pip.

According to this section in PEP440 the inclusive ordered comparison >= can be used with the standard version scheme and thus, also includes pre-release specifiers like rc.

body:
@ebrevdo: For me pip finds and installs backports.weakref (version 1.0rc1) just fine without giving any version number:
 
```bash
$ pip --version
pip 9.0.1 from /usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages (python 3.6)

$ pip install --user backports.weakref
Collecting backports.weakref
  Using cached backports.weakref-1.0rc1-py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: backports.weakref
Successfully installed backports.weakref-1.0rc1
```

The `>=1.0rc` version check from the setup.py creates the entry `Requires-Dist: backports.weakref (>=1.0rc1)` inside the wheels METADATA file. Installing the package and pulling the dependency also works fine for me with this using pip.

According to this section in [PEP440](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#inclusive-ordered-comparison) the inclusive ordered comparison `>=` can be used with the standard [version scheme](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#version-scheme) and thus, also includes pre-release specifiers like `rc`.
